The requirements relating to advertisements in Rule 4.12.1 do not apply, due to the definitional exclusion provided in section 59 of the FSMR, to any communication:
a.	made in connection with the trading of Securities on a Recognised Investment Exchange or Regulated Exchange;
b.	made for the purposes of complying with the on going reporting requirements of a Recognised Investment Exchange or the Regulator; or
c.	which is an Exempt Communication as defined in Rule 4.2.1.
For the purposes of section 59(c) of the FSMR, Exempt Communications are not Offers of Securities and therefore do not attract the Prospectus requirements in the FSMR and Rules.

MKT Rule 4.3.1(13) provides for the specific circumstance where an Exempt Offer can be directed to no more than 200 Persons who do not qualify as Professional Clients, where the Securities are to be admitted to trading on a MTF.  An Issuer seeking admission to trading of its Securities on an MTF in accordance with MKT Rule 4.3.1(13) may also, pursuant to MKT Rule 4.3.3, utilise an Exempt Offer that relies on one or more of the circumstances within MKT Rule 4.3.1, with the exception of MKT Rule 4.3.1(2).  For example, an Issuer may make a simultaneous Exempt Offer to 200 Persons under MKT rule 4.3.1(13), and an unlimited number of Professional Clients under MKT Rule 4.3.1(1).

General prohibitions and definitions. Definition of an Offer of Securities
An Offer of Securities means a communication to any person in any form or by any means, presenting information on the terms of the Offer and the Securities offered, so as to enable an investor to decide to buy or subscribe to those Securities but excluding—
(a)	any communication in connection with the trading of Securities admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange;
(b)	any communication made for the purposes of complying with the on going reporting requirements of the Regulator or a Recognised Investment Exchange; or
(c)	any other communication prescribed in Rules as an exempt communication.

REGULATORY TREATMENT OF DIGITAL SECURITIES
To use its powers under Section 58(2)(b), the FSRA expects that an Issuer will provide to it such information as is required to demonstrate that the proposed Digital Security meets the requirements of a “Security” (as defined in FSMR). In circumstances:

a)	requiring the submission of an Approved Prospectus to the FSRA, the FSRA will use the documentation submitted as part of this approval process to determine whether it will deem a Digital Security a Security under Section 58(2)(b) of FSMR; or

b)	relating to an Exempt Offer, the FSRA will review the Exempt Offer documentation for the purposes of being able to make a determination under Section 58(2)(b).  The FSRA’s review will not be for the purposes of approving the Exempt Offer itself.

The issue of Securities is not an activity that constitutes a Regulated Activity. Therefore, activities such as the issue of Shares, Debentures (Sukuk) or Warrants do not attract the Regulated Activity prohibitions in FSMR. The Offer of Securities, however, is an activity to which FSMR and the MKT Rulebook apply. Under FSMR, a Person making an Offer of Securities in the ADGM is subject to numerous disclosure requirements, unless exempt.

The Financial Promotion Restriction does not apply to any communication which—
(a)	is a non real time communication or a Solicited Real Time Communication;
(b)	relates to an investment which falls within any of paragraphs ‎87 to ‎92 of ‎Schedule 1 and which is permitted to be traded or dealt in on a relevant market; and
(c)	is required or expressly permitted to be communicated by—
(i)	the rules of the relevant market;
(ii)	a body which regulates the market; or
(iii)	a body which regulates offers or issues of investments to be traded on such a market.

question: Under what circumstances must a Relevant Person provide records to the Regulator or a law enforcement agency, and what specific types of records must be maintained for potential provision?
rag_answer: A Relevant Person must provide records to the Regulator or a law enforcement agency immediately upon request or pursuant to a valid and enforceable request, respectively [#P:c96c05de-76d2-4f05-b2ea-6f4fb9615094]. The specific types of records that must be maintained for potential provision are extensive and include, but are not limited to, documents and information obtained during initial and ongoing Customer Due Diligence (CDD) or due diligence on business partners [#P:2bb23374-a3ae-4dd1-af3e-7222ecda1e98]. Additionally, records pertaining to customer business relationships, such as business correspondence, transaction details enabling reconstruction, and internal findings on unusual or suspicious activities, must be kept [#P:2bb23374-a3ae-4dd1-af3e-7222ecda1e98]. This also encompasses internal notifications of suspicious activity, Suspicious Activity/Transaction Reports with supporting documents, communications with the FIU, and any other matters expressly required by the Rules [#P:2bb23374-a3ae-4dd1-af3e-7222ecda1e98]. These records must generally be maintained for at least six years from the date of notification, report, end of the business relationship, or completion of a transaction, whichever is latest [#P:2bb23374-a3ae-4dd1-af3e-7222ecda1e98]. If records are kept outside the ADGM, reasonable steps must be taken to ensure they are held consistently with the Rules, easily accessible, and immediately available for inspection upon the Regulator's request [#P:1c5a2e03-760c-4263-88bd-eb100e0368b4]. Furthermore, Relevant Persons must identify any secrecy or data protection legislation that might restrict access and obtain certified copies of relevant records, keeping them in a jurisdiction that allows access [#P:9ec361b2-cc02-48d4-a3f0-9c358cf6394e].

contexts.text: A Relevant Person must immediately provide to the Regulator, upon request, or a law enforcement agency, pursuant to a valid and enforceable request or requirement, a copy of the record referred to in Rule 4.5.1.

Where the records referred to in Rule 4.5.1 are kept by a Relevant Person outside the ADGM, a Relevant Person must:
(a)	take reasonable steps to ensure that the records are held in a manner consistent with these Rules;
(b)	ensure that the records are easily accessible to the Relevant Person; and
(c)	upon request by the Regulator, ensure that the records are immediately available for inspection.

A Relevant Person must:
(a)	identify where there is secrecy or data protection legislation that might restrict access without delay to the records referred to in Rule ‎4.6.1 by the Relevant Person, the Regulator or the law enforcement agencies of the U.A.E.; and
(b)	where such legislation exists, obtain without delay certified copies of the relevant records and keep such copies in a jurisdiction which allows access by those persons in (a).

The Relevant Person must provide to the Regulator a copy of:
(a)	the report provided under Rule ‎12.4.1; and
(b)	the record made under Rule ‎12.4.2(c).

Record keeping. The Authorised Person should maintain appropriate records of:
a.	credit Exposures, including aggregations of credit Exposures, by:
i.	Groups of Connected Counterparties; and
ii.	types of Counterparty as defined, for example, by the nature or geographical location of the Counterparty;
b.	credit decisions, including details of the facts or circumstances upon which a decision was made; and
c.	information relevant to assessing current credit quality.

If an Authorised Person breaches Rule 8.3.2, the Regulator will take into account the full circumstances of the case, including any remedial steps taken by another regulator or the Authorised Person, in determining what enforcement action, if any, it will take.

Disclosure to a criminal law enforcement agency. Importantly, disclosure of Confidential Information by the Regulator to a criminal law enforcement agency, whether in the U.A.E or otherwise, for the purpose of any criminal investigation or criminal proceedings under paragraph 199(1)(b)(v) is not subject to the requirements under section 199(2).

question: How should an Authorised Person calculate the Exposure value for derivatives, including written credit protection, when determining the Replacement Cost (RC) for unmargined transactions?
rag_answer: The Exposure value for derivatives, including written credit protection, when determining the Replacement Cost (RC) for unmargined transactions, is calculated as the sum of the on-balance sheet value in accordance with IFRS and an add-on for potential future Exposure, calculated according to specific rules. [#P:3.21.6.Guidance.1.] For unmargined transactions, the RC is specifically calculated using the formula: RC = max{V – C; 0}, where V represents the value of the derivative transactions within the netting set, and C is the haircut value of the net collateral held, determined according to Section A4.3. [#P:APP4.A4.6.20] An unmargined transaction is defined as one where variation margin is not exchanged, although other forms of collateral may be present. [#P:APP4.A4.6.19] Furthermore, derivative contracts subject to a one-way margining agreement in favour of the Authorised Person's counterparty are to be treated as unmargined transactions for this calculation. [#P:APP4.A4.6.21] The overall Exposure at Default (EAD) for a netting set is then determined as EAD = alpha * (RC + PFE), with alpha set at 1.4, and RC and PFE calculated according to the specified rules. [#P:APP4.A4.6.15] It is important to note that for margined netting sets, the calculated EAD is capped at the EAD of the same netting set computed on an unmargined basis. [#P:APP4.A4.6.16]

The EAD for a margined netting set is to be capped at the EAD of the same netting set calculated on an unmargined basis.

Calculation of RC for unmargined transactions. RC for unmargined transactions is calculated in accordance with the following formula:
RC = max{V – C; 0}
where:
V = the value of the derivative transactions in the netting set (constituted in accordance with Rule A4.6.18); and
C = the haircut value of the net collateral held, calculated in accordance with Section A4.3.

Derivatives and long settlement transactions – Standardised Approach to Counterparty Credit Risk (SA-CCR). EAD is to be calculated separately for each netting set. It is determined as follows:
EAD = alpha* (RC + PFE)
where:
alpha = 1.4
RC = the replacement cost calculated according to Rules A4.6.19 to A4.6.24
PFE = the amount for potential future exposure calculated according to Rule A4.6.26
Calculation of RC for unmargined transactions. Derivative contracts with a one-way margining agreement in favour of the Authorised Person's counterparty must be treated as unmargined transactions.
Calculation of RC for unmargined transactions. An unmargined transaction is a transaction in which variation margin is not exchanged. Collateral other than variation margin may be present.

In relation to on-balance sheet items:
a.	for SFTs, the Exposure value should be calculated in accordance with IFRS and the Netting requirements referred to in Rule 4.9.14;
b.	for Derivatives, including written credit protection, the Exposure value should be calculated as the sum of the on-balance sheet value in accordance with IFRS and an add-on for potential future Exposure calculated in accordance with Rules A4.6.14 to A4.6.21 of App 4; and
c.	for other on-balance sheet items, the Exposure value should be calculated based on their balance sheet values in accordance with Rule 4.9.3.

For the purpose of determining the Exposure Measure, the value of Exposures of an Authorised Person must be calculated in accordance with the International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS) subject to the following adjustments:
(a)	on-balance sheet, non-Derivative Exposures must be net of specific allowances and valuation adjustments (e.g. credit valuation adjustments);
(b)	physical or financial Collateral, guarantees or other credit risk mitigation techniques must not be used to reduce exposure values of assets; and
(c)	loans must not be netted with Deposits.

Calculation of E* for collateralised transactions other than OTC Derivative transactions and long settlement transactions. An Authorised Person using the FCCA to calculate E* must adjust both the amount of the Exposure to the Counterparty and the value of any Collateral received in support of that Counterparty to take into account possible future fluctuations in the value of either due to market movements, by using the methods and haircuts set out in Rules A4.3.6 to A4.3.29.

Where settlement does not occur on the due date and neither party has released the relevant cash or Securities, an Authorised Person faces Market Risk, namely the differential between the contract price of the Securities and their current value in the market. In this case an Authorised Person also faces a Credit Risk Exposure for the Unsettled Transaction, for which the Authorised Person is required to hold regulatory capital. The relevant Credit Risk Exposure should be included in the calculation of Credit RWA for the Authorised Person.

question: Under what conditions must Securities in a class admitted to listing and trading be traded on a Recognised Investment Exchange, and how do exemptions under section 61(3)(b) of the FSMR apply?
rag_answer: All Securities in a class admitted to listing and trading must be traded on a Recognised Investment Exchange or a Regulated Exchange [#P:1e1c0168-59f6-439b-bcc2-d705199eeb4a]. Exemptions under section 61(3)(b) of the FSMR, which prescribe types of Exempt Securities, mean that these specific securities do not require a Prospectus [#P:63c6805e-92e4-4c6d-b742-c547b94768fe]. The prohibition in section 61(1) of the FSMR, which generally requires an Approved Prospectus for securities to be admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange, does not apply to these Exempt Securities, subject to Rule 4.4.2 [#P:f70272ac-30bf-4e62-92d7-8b863f75cdf9]. These Exempt Securities include shares representing less than 10% of the same class over 12 months, shares issued in substitution without increasing issued capital, securities offered in connection with a takeover offer or merger where equivalent information is available, securities in a rights issue or free share offer to existing shareholders if certain conditions are met, securities offered to directors or employees under specific conditions, shares from conversion or exchange of other securities, securities already admitted to trading on another Recognised Investment Exchange or Regulated Exchange for over 18 months with ongoing obligations met and a summary document approved by the Regulator, and securities offered in connection with specific issues under Rules 9.7.1 or 9.7.4 [#P:16a48ee7-becd-40f8-8af0-17dbcd09dfc0]. Similarly, for Units, all Units in a class admitted to trading, including those specified under Rule 3.3.5, must be traded on a Recognised Investment Exchange [#P:8304d78c-757e-45d8-a9b6-fd855e1513ab]. contexts.text: The Regulator may also modify one or more requirements of this chapter for an Exempt Offeror who wishes to voluntarily comply with the Listing Rules in order to include its Securities on the Official List and thereby seek admission to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange. Without such a modification an Exempt Offeror cannot have its Securities included in the Official List. This is because section 50(3) of the FSMR requires that a Recognised Investment Exchange shall not permit trading of Securities on its facilities unless those Securities are admitted to, and not suspended from, the Official List.

The prohibition in section 61(1) of the FSMR does not apply, subject to the requirement in Rule 4.4.2, to the admission to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange of Securities that are Exempt Securities under Rule 4.4.1.

DIGITAL SECURITIES & TRADING VENUES
Recognised Investment Exchanges (RIEs)
Pursuant to section 50(3) of FSMR, a RIE shall not permit trading of Securities on its facilities unless those Securities are admitted to, and not suspended from, the Official List.  Section 61(1) of FSMR is linked to section 50(3), such that an Issuer cannot ‘have Securities admitted to trading on a RIE, unless there is an Approved Prospectus in relation to the relevant Securities’.  An Issuer therefore wanting to have its Securities traded on a RIE needs to have such Securities:

a)	admitted to the Official List of Securities (maintained by FSRA); and

b)	offered by way of an Approved Prospectus.
Pursuant to section 52(5) of the FSMR, to be admitted to the Official List a Listed Entity's Securities must be admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange.
Exempt Offers in respect of Units. All Units in a class of Securities admitted to trading including those specified under Rule 3.3.5 must be traded on a Recognised Investment Exchange.
All Securities in a class of Securities admitted to listing and trading including pursuant to Rule 4.4.1 must be traded on a Recognised Investment Exchange or a Regulated Exchange.

The Regulator also has the power under section 61(3) of the FSMR to prescribe certain types of:
a.	Offers of Securities as "Exempt Offers"; and
b.	Securities to be "Exempt Securities".
Pursuant to section 58 of FSMR, Exempt Offers and Exempt Securities do not require a Prospectus.

The requirements relating to advertisements in Rule 4.12.1 do not apply, due to the definitional exclusion provided in section 59 of the FSMR, to any communication:
a.	made in connection with the trading of Securities on a Recognised Investment Exchange or Regulated Exchange;
b.	made for the purposes of complying with the on going reporting requirements of a Recognised Investment Exchange or the Regulator; or
c.	which is an Exempt Communication as defined in Rule 4.2.1.

question: When can an Insurer use the assets held by a Related entity to figure out the Minimum Fund Capital Requirement, and how does this connect to the flexibility for pooled investments?
rag_answer: An Insurer may calculate components of the Minimum Fund Capital Requirement by referencing the invested assets held by a Related entity, rather than the Insurer's interest in that Related entity, provided the Regulator grants written approval [#P:12, APP8.A8.3.2]. This provision allows for flexibility when an Insurer's affairs are arranged such that invested assets attributable to a Long Term Insurance Fund are held within a Related entity [#P:12, APP8.A8.3.2]. In such cases, the appendix is interpreted as if the assets held by the Related entity were directly held by the Long Term Insurance Fund [#P:12, APP8.A8.3.2]. This flexibility is particularly beneficial for Insurers whose investments are managed on a pooled basis within a Group or who utilize specialist Subsidiaries for investment management [#P:12, APP8.A8.3.2.Guidance]. The effect is that the Insurer can "look through" the corporate structure and apply the relevant appendix provisions to the assets of the Related entity as if they were the Insurer's own [#P:12, APP8.A8.3.2.Guidance]. However, this flexibility does not exempt the Insurer from the requirement for segregation of assets under Rule 3.4 [#P:12, APP8.A8.3.2.Guidance]. The calculation of the Minimum Fund Capital Requirement is analogous to the calculation of the Minimum Capital Requirement for other Insurers, as outlined in APP4 [#P:12, APP8.A8.1.1.Guidance.2].

contexts.text: Where an Insurer arranges its affairs such that Invested Assets attributable to a Long Term Insurance Fund are held in a Related entity, the Insurer may, with the written approval of the Regulator, calculate components of the Minimum Fund Capital Requirement by reference to the interest of the Long Term Insurance Fund in the assets that are held by the Related entity, instead of by reference to the interest that the Long Term Insurance Fund has in that Related entity.  In that case this appendix shall be interpreted as though the assets (representing the Long Term Insurance Fund's interest) held by the Related entity were held directly by the Long Term Insurance Fund.

The effect of Rule ‎A8.3.2 is to provide flexibility for Insurers whose investments are managed on a pooled basis within a Group, or which establish specialist Subsidiaries to manage their investments.  While the Insurer's asset in such cases is a balance with, or investment in, a Related entity, this Rule permits the Insurer to 'look through' the corporate arrangement and apply this appendix to the assets of the Related entity as though they were the Insurer's own.  This flexibility extends to Invested Assets attributable to Long Term Insurance Funds, though this provision does not provide any exemption from Rule 3.4 in respect of segregation of assets.

Where an Insurer arranges its affairs such that its Invested Assets are held in a Related entity, the Insurer may, with the written approval of the Regulator, calculate components of its Minimum Capital Requirement by reference to the Insurer's interest in the assets that are held by the Related entity, instead of by reference to the interest that the Insurer has in that Related entity.  In that case this appendix shall be interpreted as though the assets (representing the Insurer's interest) held by the Related entity were held directly by the Insurer.

While the Insurer's asset in such cases is a balance with, or investment in, a Related entity, this Rule permits the Insurer to 'look through' the corporate arrangement and apply this appendix to the assets of the Related entity as though they were the Insurer's own.

The effect of Rule ‎A4.3.2 is to provide flexibility for Insurers whose investments are managed on a pooled basis within a Group, or which establish specialist Subsidiaries to manage their investments.  While the Insurer's asset in such cases is a balance with, or investment in, a Related entity, this Rule permits the Insurer to 'look through' the corporate arrangement and apply this appendix to the assets of the Related entity as though they were the Insurer's own.

Where an Insurer arranges its affairs such that Invested Assets attributable to a segment are held in a Related entity, the Insurer may, with the written approval of the Regulator, calculate components of the relevant Minimum Segmental Capital Requirement by reference to the Insurer's interest in the assets that are held by the Related entity, instead of by reference to the interest that the Insurer has in that Related entity.  In that case this appendix shall be interpreted as though the assets (representing the Insurer's interest) held by the Related entity were held directly by the Insurer.

Subject to Rule ‎A8.3.2, an Insurer must calculate those components of the Minimum Fund Capital Requirement in respect of a Long Term Insurance Fund, which are relevant to assets, in respect of every asset that is attributable to the Long Term Insurance Fund.

Where Rule ‎A6.3.3 is applied, the Insurer still needs to calculate the Minimum Segmental Capital Requirement for the specialist investment segment, in respect of the Invested Assets which the specialist investment segment owns.  Two segments would therefore be required to hold capital in respect of those Invested Assets.

The Minimum Fund Capital Requirement is calculated on a basis that is analogous to the basis of calculation of the Minimum Capital Requirement for Insurers other than Cell Companies, as set out in ‎APP4.

This appendix sets out the manner in which an Insurer that conducts Long Term Insurance Business through a Long Term Insurance Fund is required to calculate the Minimum Fund Capital Requirement in respect of each Long Term Insurance Fund.

question: What are the payment requirements for someone applying for an ADGM Sustainability Linked Bond and who already has a designation under Rule 10.1.1?
rag_answer: A person applying for an ADGM Sustainability-Linked Bond Designation must pay an application fee of $2,000 to the Regulator, irrespective of whether they already hold a designation under Rule 10.1.1. [#P:a0e78247-fd29-4fda-8fdc-07ce6c83f37b] The application process for an ADGM Green Bond Designation or ADGM Sustainability-Linked Bond Designation requires specific documentation and adherence to prescribed forms. [#P:e22d7abf-b083-440b-bcf3-81dd0de3cf4b] This includes providing information on the relevant Qualifying Principles the Security intends to comply with, certification of alignment with these principles, details of the appointed external review provider, and a copy of the pre-issuance external review. [#P:e22d7abf-b083-440b-bcf3-81dd0de3cf4b] Furthermore, if any material change, error, or omission relevant to the application arises between its submission and the grant of the designation, the Issuer must promptly inform the Regulator in writing. [#P:390cbc39-3c6a-43ed-b1ec-dc9be8f2cdd1] It is important to note that obtaining these designations is not a mandatory requirement under FSMR or applicable Rules for marketing materials, Prospectus, or other communications relating to Securities. [#P:9dc55b71-e2af-45cc-801f-375286bfc31d] However, a Security should not be promoted as an ADGM Sustainability-Linked Debenture unless the Issuer has applied for and been granted the relevant designation from the Regulator. [#P:c20c837e-d33a-41eb-abf1-28ff11edbc07] Upon the grant of the designation, the Regulator will publish the Security's details on its website. [#P:566f7fb5-cc1a-42f9-9f6e-fa4bb5688b1f]

As a result, the requirements set out in this section will not apply to any Person that elects not to obtain an ADGM Green Bond Designation or ADGM Sustainability-Linked Bond Designation, or does not wish to use the ADGM Green Bond mark or ADGM Sustainability Linked-Bond mark in the marketing materials, Prospectus or other communications relating to relevant Securities.

question: When a Payment Order is initiated through a Payment Initiation Service Provider, what are the obligations of the Payment Service Provider regarding the provision of transaction details to the Payer and Payee, and how does Rule 19.5.3 affect these obligations?
rag_answer: When a Payment Order is initiated through a Payment Initiation Service Provider, the Payment Service Provider has specific obligations to obtain and disclose transaction details to the Payer and, where applicable, the Payee. Rule 19.5.1 mandates that immediately after the initiation of a Payment Order, the Payment Service Provider must provide confirmation of successful initiation, a reference for identifying the transaction, the transaction amount, details of any charges, information on exchange rates if used, the date of receipt of the Payment Order, and the Credit Value Date [#P:a48a07c2-0731-4505-939e-07110e2af622]. Rule 19.5.2 further clarifies that in such scenarios, the Payment Service Provider must obtain the reference for the Payment Transaction from the Payment Initiation Service Provider to fulfill its obligations under Rule 19.5.1, unless an exclusion under Rule 19.6.2 applies [#P:e26ca08e-5397-4da6-bc33-13c0bdc73939]. Rule 19.5.3 itself does not directly affect these obligations but rather outlines the general requirements for providing transaction details immediately after initiation, which are then specifically addressed in Rule 19.5.2 concerning Payment Initiation Service Providers.

Non-execution or defective or late execution of Payment Transactions initiated by the Payee. The Payee’s Payment Service Provider is liable to the Payee for the correct transmission of the Payment Order to the Payer’s Payment Service Provider in accordance with Rule 19.15.2(4).

The Payer’s Payment Service Provider is liable to the Payer for the correct execution of the Payment Transaction unless it can prove to the Payer and, where relevant, to the Payee’s Payment Service Provider, that the Payee’s Payment Service Provider received the amount of the Payment Transaction in accordance with Rule 19.15.2(1) and (2).

question: What must a Recognised Clearing House do to make sure that people or types of people are designated correctly, and how does this relate to market operations?
rag_answer: A Recognised Clearing House must ensure that its procedures for designating persons or types of persons are designed to prevent individuals or groups whose failure to meet obligations would adversely affect market operations from being designated, or remaining designated, as such [#P:55576d4c-9a95-4fb8-8fd6-9462a2a1153b]. This is crucial for maintaining market integrity and operational stability, as the failure of designated non-members to meet their obligations in respect of market contracts could impact the market's functioning [#P:817f6968-e9c3-4cb9-89c7-cf942d033bb4, #P:55576d4c-9a95-4fb8-8fd6-9462a2a1153b]. The Default Rules may establish provisions for designated non-members that are similar to those for members of the Recognised Clearing House, ensuring consistent application of rules where appropriate [#P:817f6968-e9c3-4cb9-89c7-cf942d033bb4]. Furthermore, the Recognised Clearing House must have adequate compliance procedures to monitor and enforce its Clearing Rules and Default Rules, investigate complaints promptly, and make referrals to the Regulator when necessary, all contributing to the proper functioning and oversight of the market [#P:0113eca5-f6b2-4a4b-b9f4-abf5f2a35e12].

The procedures in Rule 4.5.9 must be designed to ensure that:
(a)	a Person is not, or does not remain, designated if failure by him to meet his obligations in respect of one or more Market Contracts would adversely affect the operation of the market; and
(b)	a description of persons is not, or does not remain, designated if failure by a Person of that description to meet his obligations in respect of one or more Market Contracts would affect operation of the market.

The Default Rules may make the same or similar provision, in relation to Designated Non-Members that have been designated as such in accordance with the procedures mentioned in Rule 4.5.9, as in relation to Members of the Recognised Clearing House.

A Recognised Clearing House shall hold capital more than or equal to the sum of capital calculated in respect of the following risks.
(a)	Winding down or restructuring activities. Six months' gross operational expenses.
(b)	Operational risks. A Recognised Clearing House shall calculate its capital requirement for operational risks using either the Basic Indicator Approach or, with prior authorisation from the Regulator, the Standardised Approach or the Alternative Standardised Approach, both as provided specifically in Appendix 7.3 and generally in Appendix 7 of PRU.
(c)	Credit, counterparty credit and market risks. A Recognised Clearing House shall calculate its capital requirements as the sum of 10% of its risk-weighted exposure amounts for credit and counterparty credit risk and its capital requirements for market risk calculated in accordance with Appendix 6 of PRU, subject to the following.
(i)	For the calculation of the risk-weighted exposure amounts for credit risk and counterparty credit risk, a Recognised Clearing House shall apply the Credit Risk Capital Requirement (CRCOM) method in section 4.8 of PRU.
(ii)	Where a Recognised Clearing House does not use its own resources, the Recognised Clearing House shall apply a risk weight of 250% to its exposure stemming from any contributions to the default fund of another Clearing house and a risk weight of 2% to any trade exposures with another Clearing house.
(d)	Business risk. A Recognised Clearing House shall submit to the Regulator for approval its own estimate of the capital necessary to cover losses resulting from business risk based on reasonably foreseeable adverse scenarios relevant to its business model. The capital requirement for business risk shall be equal to the approved estimate and shall be subject to a minimum amount of 25% of its annual gross operational expenses.

A Recognised Clearing House must establish explicit Clearing Rules, Default Rules and procedures that address fully any credit losses it may face as a result of any individual or combined default among its Members and other participants with respect to any of their obligations to the Recognised Clearing House. Such Clearing Rules, Default Rules and procedures should:
(a)	address how any potentially uncovered credit losses would be allocated, including the repayment of any funds the Recognised Clearing House may borrow from its liquidity providers; and
(b)	indicate the Recognised Clearing House's process to replenish any financial resources that it may employ during a stress event, so that it can continue to operate in a safe and sound manner.

A Recognised Clearing House must, for the purposes of managing its exposures and risk and the requirements in Rules ‎4.10.7 and ‎4.10.8:
(a)	mark participant positions to market and collect variation margin at least daily to limit the build-up of current exposures;
(b)	have necessary authority and operational capacity to make intra day margin calls and payments, both scheduled and unscheduled, to participants; and
(c)	regularly review and validate its margin system to ensure that it operates effectively and as intended.

In some instances, certain types of assets which are not considered to have low credit, liquidity and market risks may be acceptable for credit purposes if the Recognised Clearing House sets and enforces appropriately conservative haircuts and concentration limits and appropriate collateral risk management procedures are put in place by the Recognised Clearing House. A Recognised Clearing House may, in some circumstances, accept the deliverable of a contract as collateral against the contract for exchange.

question: Under what conditions may a Relevant Person rely on a third party for CDD information, considering the equivalence of AML/TFS regulations to FATF standards?
rag_answer: A Relevant Person may rely on a third party to conduct Customer Due Diligence (CDD) elements, provided specific conditions are met, primarily concerning the equivalence of AML/TFS regulations to FATF standards and the nature of the third party. The third party must be subject to regulation, including AML/TFS compliance, by a competent authority in a jurisdiction with equivalent AML/TFS regulations to FATF standards, and be supervised for compliance. [#P:8fdad81d-b309-441b-a66d-afa6d42d5275, #P:8a894691-4b15-41d9-849e-d49810c564ac] The Relevant Person must immediately obtain the necessary CDD information from the third party and take adequate steps to ensure certified copies of documents are available without delay upon request. [#P:8fdad81d-b309-441b-a66d-afa6d42d5275] Crucially, the third party must not have relied on any exceptions from CDD requirements that the Relevant Person intends to use, and all information must be up-to-date. [#P:8fdad81d-b309-441b-a66d-afa6d42d5275] An exception exists for Group members, which need not meet the foreign jurisdiction equivalence requirement if the Group adheres to equivalent FATF standards through a Group-wide policy or is supervised at the Group level by a competent authority in an equivalent jurisdiction. [#P:32b078c5-682a-457e-9d94-482e8a9af33e] Factors to consider when assessing equivalence include mutual evaluations, membership in FATF or regional groups, contextual factors like political stability and corruption, evidence of recent criticism, and co-operation arrangements between regulators. [#P:06794d47-81ee-49d0-bf3a-58e87a031da4] If a Relevant Person is not reasonably satisfied with the third party's identification and verification, they must perform the CDD themselves to address any deficiencies, while remaining ultimately responsible for compliance. [#P:0ea9f5

contexts.text: If a Relevant Person relies on a third party located in a foreign jurisdiction to conduct one or more elements of CDD on its behalf, the Relevant Person must ensure that the foreign jurisdiction has AML/TFS regulations which are equivalent to the standards in the FATF Recommendations (see Rule ‎9.1.1(3)(c)).

Where a Relevant Person relies on a member of its Group to conduct one or more of the elements of CDD on its behalf, such Group member need not meet the condition in (3)(c) if:
(a)	the Group is subject to policies and requirements equivalent to FATF standards, either:
(i)	where the Group applies and implements a Group-wide policy on CDD and record-keeping which is equivalent to the standards set by FATF; or
(ii)	where the effective implementation of those CDD and record-keeping requirements and AML/TFS programmes are supervised at Group level by a Non-ADGM Financial Services Regulator or other competent authority in a jurisdiction with AML/TFS regulations that are equivalent to the standards set out in the FATF Recommendations;
(b)	no exception from identification obligations has been applied in the original identification process; and
(c)	a written statement is received from the introducing member of the Relevant Person's Group confirming that:
(i)	the customer has been identified in accordance with the relevant standards under (4)(a) and (b);
(ii)	any identification evidence can be accessed by the Relevant Person without delay; and
(iii)	the identification evidence will be kept for at least six years.

The requirement in (1) does not apply if the Relevant Person can satisfy the Regulator that the relevant branch, subsidiary or Group entity is subject to regulation, including AML/TFS regulation, by a Financial Services Regulator or other competent authority in a country or jurisdiction with AML/TFS regulations which are equivalent to the standards set out in the FATF Recommendations and is supervised for compliance with such regulations.
In (1), a Relevant Person may rely on the information previously obtained by a third party which covers one or more elements of CDD.

If a Relevant Person is not reasonably satisfied that a customer or Beneficial Owners has been identified and verified by a third party in a manner consistent with these Rules, the Relevant Person must immediately perform the CDD itself with respect to any deficiencies identified.
(6)	Notwithstanding the Relevant Person's reliance on a Person in ‎9.1.1(1), the Relevant Person remains responsible for compliance with, and liable for any failure to meet the CDD requirements in the AML Rulebook.

question: When does an Authorised Person have to pay extra fees to set up a branch outside ADGM?
rag_answer: An Authorised Person with its registered head office in ADGM must pay an application fee when seeking approval from the Regulator to establish a branch outside ADGM. [#P:363c3cff-9b23-461e-a521-d56d8c16221f] This fee is equivalent to 50% of the highest application fee stipulated in Chapter 3 of the Rules for the Regulated Activities intended to be conducted from the proposed branch. [#P:363c3cff-9b23-461e-a521-d56d8c16221f] Furthermore, if an Authorised Person already operates a branch outside ADGM and conducts Regulated Activities from it, an annual supervision fee is payable to the Regulator. [#P:47c0063b-14dc-43a0-8e44-7b5238750a0c] This annual fee is also set at 50% of the highest annual supervision fee applicable to those Regulated Activities undertaken from the branch. [#P:47c0063b-14dc-43a0-8e44-7b5238750a0c] The initial supervision fee for such a branch is prorated and must be paid in accordance with Rule 1.2.2(a). [#P:47c0063b-14dc-43a0-8e44-7b5238750a0c] Additionally, the Regulator reserves the right to impose a supplementary fee if it anticipates incurring substantial additional costs or expending significant effort in processing an application, authorisation, or filing, or in conducting ongoing supervision. [#P:64a0df5a-e946-4496-9fd3-244340c2a080] An Authorised Person with one or more branches outside ADGM is also required to implement and maintain Credit Risk policies tailored to each local market and its regulatory conditions. [#P:46c299a3-a9ee-4302-864b-f24ddbe4151e]

contexts.text: Where an Authorised Person that has its registered head office in ADGM applies to the Regulator for approval to establish a branch outside ADGM, it must pay to the Regulator an application fee equal to 50% of the highest application fee set out in Chapter 3 of these Rules for those Regulated Activities it seeks to undertake from the proposed branch.

question: What is the annual supervision fee obligation for an Authorised Person with a Financial Services Permission to carry on the Regulated Activity of Providing Money Services, specifically when engaging in both Currency Exchange and Payment Services?
rag_answer: An Authorised Person with a Financial Services Permission to carry on the Regulated Activity of Providing Money Services, and which engages in both Currency Exchange and Payment Services, is obligated to pay an annual supervision fee of $25,000 to the Regulator. question: Under what circumstances must an Authorised Person notify the Regulator about a Controller, and how does this relate to the assessment of an unacceptable Controller?
rag_answer: An Authorised Person must notify the Regulator about a Controller in specific circumstances related to the acquisition or increase of control, which directly informs the Regulator's assessment of whether that Controller is acceptable. The Regulator may consider a person an unacceptable Controller as a result of notifications given by a firm, including those under GEN 8.8.11(2), or through supervisory work [#P:cd250838-4f1d-410d-acd7-056e3364ab2b]. If the Regulator determines an existing Controller is unacceptable, they must notify the Controller and the Authorised Person in writing and may require specific actions from both parties [#P:700c56f8-6306-45c7-802d-f8479f2bd069]. Furthermore, a person notified as an unacceptable Controller must not proceed with any proposed acquisition of control of the Authorised Person [#P:7634a2d6-9c5d-433a-89a2-6610fb5bbc18]. The Regulator issues a final notice to approve a person as a Controller, approve them subject to conditions, or declare them unacceptable, which may necessitate the disposal of their holdings [#P:ed5a6e8d-910e-40a1-bc99-a3e047d570f1, #P:a84ca5b1-3e5c-4db0-877c-892c2bd34e4b]. The Regulator's powers in relation to an unacceptable Controller include requiring the Authorised Person or the Controller to take specified actions [#P:219dc916-c224-40af-af0b-4a217189ef54].

contexts.text: Controllers - Our approval. An Accepted Virtual Asset may be deemed suitable for use by more than one Authorised Person, subject to each Authorised Person satisfying the FSRA that it can meet the regulatory requirements in respect of the specific Accepted Virtual Asset.  For example, an MTF using Virtual Assets is required by COBS Rule 17.7.4  to notify the FSRA of any new Accepted Virtual Asset proposed to be admitted to trading on its facilities.  Though the MTF may propose to admit to trading a commonly used and traded Virtual Asset, the MTF’s controls, for example, relating to identity/transaction monitoring of a certain distributed ledger may not yet be fully developed. In such circumstances, the FSRA may require the MTF to delay the commencement of trading until such time that suitable controls have been developed and implemented.

question: When does a FinTech Participant have to stop its activities in the RegLab, and what role does the Regulator play in changing or cancelling their permission?
rag_answer:
A FinTech Participant must cease carrying on Regulated Activities within the RegLab upon the expiry of its RegLab Financial Services Permission (FSP), unless an application to extend the two-year validity period is made at least three months prior to its expiry or as otherwise agreed by the Regulator [#P:b9c2a532-09b8-4cb8-960c-39847c2128e7, #P:c58f02e6-0701-4d82-899f-a693d180b776]. Failure to satisfy the necessary criteria by the FSP expiry date necessitates exiting the RegLab, either by migrating to the full authorisation regime or employing an exit strategy [#P:b9c2a532-09b8-4cb8-960c-39847c2128e7, #P:c58f02e6-0701-4d82-899f-a693d180b776]. If the FinTech Participant is unable to satisfy the above criteria, it will be required to cease carrying on the Regulated Activity of Developing Financial Technology Services within the RegLab. Please refer to section 8 below for more details.
